*[Bug 18782] seq.Date() should not always coerce to double*
<https://bugs.r-project.org/show_bug.cgi?id=18782>

--- Comment #8 from Martin Maechler (<mailto:maechler@stat.math.ethz.ch|maechler@stat.math.ethz.ch>) ---
(In reply to Benjamin Schwendinger from comment #7)
I would say that you (and your checks/tests) typically should *not* care,
i.e., not rely on the internal representation,
in the same sense you should not rely on '1' being double (even though chances
are quite low, this will ever change).

Still, if you want a sure compact way, you could also use something like
 `.Date(12345L)`

But to re-iterate: I don't think you should write tests / checks based on
assuming Date (or POSIXct) to be internally coded via double or via integer.

To finally answer your question: Now, the above will *not* work currently:
both cases return identical (internally double precision) Date objects.
---> see my "aside" comment in the related bug 17672.

(In reply to Heather Turner from comment #6)
> The current behaviour (in R 4.4.1) is to first recycle `x`/`y` as necessary

> I'm pretty sure no one would want this.

I agree; the current behaviour is plain wrong.
Also,  `grid :: grid.text(label, x, y)`  *does* recycle `x, y` but not the

Still (in spite of `grid`s), I agree we should change according to your comment
#7,
```
if (length(labels) > (n <- max(length(x), length(y))) && n >= 1) {
   ## use labels[1:n]  and warn about length(labels) >= .. or "omitting
labels[...]"
}
if (length(labels) < n) { 
  ## recycle labels to length `n`  without a warning
}
```

--- Comment #2 from Sebastian Meyer (<mailto:seb.meyer@fau.de|seb.meyer@fau.de>) ---
So this will increase the number of notes from checking under
`_R_CHECK_XREFS_MIND_SUSPECT_ANCHORS_=TRUE`. 

> Check if package-anchored Rd cross-references are to *files* (and not aliases). Default: false. 

(which means *non-file* links get flagged)

For example:

```
$ _R_CHECK_XREFS_MIND_SUSPECT_ANCHORS_=TRUE R --vanilla -s -e
'tools:::.check_Rd_xrefs("tools")'
Non-file package-anchored link(s) in Rd file 'check_packages_in_dir.Rd':
  '[parallel]{parLapply}'

See section 'Cross-references' in the 'Writing R Extensions' manual.
```

This check option is surprisingly recent

```
r78674 | hornik | 2020-06-10 16:01:47 +0200 (Wed, 10 Jun 2020) | 2 lines

Optionally check for package-anchored Rd xrefs linking to aliases
instead of files.
```

I was trying to see how I could easily reproduce Lluis' list and did so
successfully by "inverting" the code in `.check_Rd_xrefs()` to "suspect"
historical file-based links rather than aliases. I am wondering if the meaning
of `_R_CHECK_XREFS_MIND_SUSPECT_ANCHORS_` should be changed (to simplify
checking for old file-based links) or whether this env var should be considered
obsolete.


PS: I changed the severity level to enhancement as I failed to see a bug (these
xrefs still work).

*[Bug 18816] New: Checks and diffs for <pkg>/demo/*R*
<https://bugs.r-project.org/show_bug.cgi?id=18816>

            Bug ID: 18816
           Summary: Checks and diffs for <pkg>/demo/*R
           Product: R
           Version: R-devel (trunk)
          Hardware: Other
                OS: Linux
            Status: UNCONFIRMED
          Severity: normal
          Priority: P5
         Component: Wishlist
          Assignee: <mailto:R-core@R-project.org|R-core@R-project.org>
          Reporter: <mailto:Torsten.Hothorn@r-project.org|Torsten.Hothorn@r-project.org>

AFAIKS, 

    R CMD check --test-dir="demo" <src_pkg>

would treat demo/ as the tests/ default, that is, running all *R files and,
when supplied, compare the resulting Rout to Rout.save reference output.

This is really nice, as it provides a simple route to checking demos.

However, 

    R CMD build <pkg_dir>

does currently not allow Rout.save files in demo/:

* excluding invalid files
Subdirectory 'demo' contains invalid file names:
  ‘mtram.Rout.save’

May I suggest to rethink this behaviour in favour of treating demo/ like tests/
in this respect, allowing reference output for demos to be shipped with the
source package?

Best, Torsten

*[Bug 18817] New: kappa(x, exact = TRUE, norm = "2") badly wrong for exactly singular 'x'*
<https://bugs.r-project.org/show_bug.cgi?id=18817>

            Bug ID: 18817
           Summary: kappa(x, exact = TRUE, norm = "2") badly wrong for
                    exactly singular 'x'
           Product: R
           Version: R-devel (trunk)
          Hardware: Other
                OS: Other
            Status: UNCONFIRMED
          Severity: normal
          Priority: P5
         Component: Accuracy
          Assignee: <mailto:R-core@R-project.org|R-core@R-project.org>
          Reporter: <mailto:jaganmn@mcmaster.ca|jaganmn@mcmaster.ca>

```
> x <- diag(6L); x[6L, 6L] <- 0
> kappa(x, exact = TRUE, norm = "2")
[1] 1
> .kappa_tri(x, exact = TRUE, norm = "2")
[1] 1
```

where the result should be `Inf`, not `1`, because `x` is singular.  `Inf`
would be returned if the denominator of the condition number were computed as
the minimum singular value of `x`, rather than (as currently) the minimum
positive singular value of `x`.

`rcond` does not have this bug mainly because it does not support the 2-norm.
